text: bayram English [edit]Noun [edit]bayram (plural bayrams) - In Turkic cultures, a nationally celebrated festival or holiday, whether secular or religious. - 2017, Douglas A. Howard, A History of the Ottoman Empire, page 126: - The two bayrams were occasions for family visiting and public celebrations. Azerbaijani [edit]Etymology [edit]From Proto-Common Turkic *badram, probably from Iranian (see the reconstruction page for more). Compare Karakhanid بَذْرَمْ (baḏram), Sogdian [script needed] (ptrʾm /patrăm/, “calm, peace”), Persian پدرام (pedrâm, “lucky, happy”). Pronunciation [edit]Noun [edit]bayram (definite accusative bayramı, plural bayramlar) - holiday - Bu gün bayram günüdür. ― Today is a holiday. - (figuratively) a very happy situation - feast, festival, fete Declension [edit]Crimean Tatar [edit]Etymology [edit]From Proto-Common Turkic *badram Noun [edit]bayram Declension [edit]References [edit]French [edit]Noun [edit]bayram m (plural bayrams) - alternative form of baïram Gagauz [edit]Etymology [edit]Inherited from Old Anatolian Turkish بَیْرَامْ (bayram), from Proto-Turkic *badram (“feast”).[1][2] Compare Azerbaijani bayram and Turkish bayram. Pronunciation [edit]Noun [edit]bayram (definite accusative bayramı, plural bayramnar) - (dialectal) holiday - Synonym: yortu - (religion, dialectal) feast, religious festival - Synonym: yortu - whirlpool Declension [edit]References [edit]- ^ András Rajki, A Concise Gagauz Dictionary with etymologies and Turkish, Azerbaijani, Crimean Tatar and Turkmen cognates, 2007 - ^ Nişanyan, Sevan (2002–), “bayram”, in Nişanyan Sözlük Further reading [edit]- N. A Baskakov, editor (1972), “байрам”, in Gagauzsko-Russko-Moldavskij Slovarʹ [Gagauz-Russian-Moldovan Dictionary], Moskva: Izdatelʹstvo Sovetskaja Enciklopedija, →ISBN, page 68 - Kopuşçu M. İ., Todorova S. A., Kiräkova T.İ., editors (2019), “bayram”, in Gagauzça-rusça sözlük: klaslar 5-12, Komrat: Gagauziya M.V. Maruneviç adına Bilim-Aaraştırma merkezi, →ISBN, page 28 Turkish [edit]Etymology [edit]From Ottoman Turkish بیرام (bayram), from Proto-Turkic *badram (“feast”). Nişanyan and Clauson suggests a borrowing from Iranian source,[1][2] despite Dīwān Lughāt al-Turk stating a Turkic etymology.[3] See the reconstruction page for more. Alternatively, related to Proto-Mongolic *bayar (“joy”), whence also Mongolian баяр (bajar). Cognate with Tatar бәйрәм (bäyräm), Kazakh мейрам (meiram), Kyrgyz майрам (mayram), Khakas пайрам (payram), Bashkir байрам (bayram), Azerbaijani bayram, etc. Pronunciation [edit]Noun [edit]bayram (definite accusative bayramı, plural bayramlar) - Eid, religious festival. - Religious festival of any variety. - A public holiday, religious or not, especially national holidays. - Ulusal Egemenlik ve Çocuk Bayramı ― National Sovereignty and Children's Day - Cumhuriyet Bayramı ― Republic Day - Zafer Bayramı ― Victory Day - (figuratively) A very happy situation.
